sub_title: Senior scientist "Induced Seismicity" at The Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI)
summary: Geoscience is my passion. I have worked with seismic inversions that was applied to many types of experimental configurations. Some years ago, I focused on the time-lapse monitoring of the injection of steam, water and CO2 in different geological settings. My next challenge is to work with the induced seismicity due to the gas production in the North of the Netherlands.

I worked together with Prof. dr. ir. Kees Wapenaar, Dr. Karl-Heinz Wolf and Dr. Danijela Sijacic.', 'title': 'Scientific researcher', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'Delft, The Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2004}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2007}}, 'company': 'The Technical University of Delft', 'description': 'Researcher at the Technical University of Delft, Department of Geotechnology (the Netherlands). 

I developed a geophysical imaging method and applied the technique on real seismic data to detect injected CO2. The method was successfully tested on real seismic data from a time-lapse cross-well experiment in Nagaoka, Niigata prefecture, Japan. I showed that it was possible to detect the injected CO2 (10400 tons) at 1100 m depth. In addition, I worked with time-lapse monitoring of steam injection in tar sand using cross-well data (Ref: TL 1.3 SEG 2006). These cross-well data were provided by Paulsson Geophysical Services. The project was supported with a Veni scholarship from STW (Stichting Technologie en Wetenschap). 

I collaborated with Dr. Zigiu Xue (RITE), Dr. Osamu Nishizawa (The Geological Survey of Japan, Tsukuba) and Hideki Saito, Dai Nobuoka (OYO).', 'title': 'Scientific researcher', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'Delft, The Netherlands', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2001}, 'end': {'month': 6, 'day': None, 'year': 2004}}, 'company': 'The Technical University of Delft', 'description': 'Post. doctoral work at the Technical University of Delft, Department of Geotechnology (the Netherlands). 

I participated in the EU sponsored project ATLAS about geophysical time-lapse monitoring of oil/gas reservoirs. Prof. dr. ir. Kees Wapenaar was my superior. ATLAS was a collaboration between TU Delft (The Netherlands), NUST (Norway), CGG (France), AGIP (Italy), Shell (The Netherlands), Stat Oil (Norway) and Norsk Hydro (Norway). 

I worked with time-lapse reflection data from the Gullfaks - and Troll field in the North Sea. 

Taught course in geostatistical methods (eg. Kriging) used on geophysical and geological data.  

Additionally, I supervised PhD and undergraduate students.', 'title': 'Post.
